channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hong Kong Government’s Strategy on Protesters: Wait Them Out
item.description: The city’s top leader and his aides are said to hope that the disruption of the demonstrations will eventually turn the public against the pro-democracy protests. .
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Outside the government headquarters in Hong Kong on Wednesday, demonstrators reacted to a speech by a student leader of the pro-democracy campaign.

item.title: U.S. to Increase Production of the Ebola Drug ZMapp, but May Not Meet Demand
item.description: Despite the new efforts, supplies of the drug, ZMapp, are expected to be limited to hundreds or thousands of treatment courses by early next year, which would not be nearly enough if the epidemic continues to spiral out of control.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK
item.media:description: Proteins glowing under ultraviolet light on a type of plant used to produce the drug ZMapp.

item.title: Ebola Suspected in U.N. Staffer’s Death
item.description: The victim was Liberian who had worked for the United Nations peacekeeping mission in her country.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Man in U.S. With Ebola Had Been Screened to Fly, but System is Spotty
item.description: Since the Ebola virus began spreading through West Africa, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has been pushing the worst-hit countries to implement screening for air passengers.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD and JAD MOUAWAD

item.title: At 17, Setting Off Protests That Roil Hong Kong
item.description: Joshua Wong, a 17-year-old student, has been at the center of the democracy movement as young activists represent a troubling confirmation for officials that their generation is the one most alienated from Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Mr. Wong addressing demonstrators in Hong Kong on Wednesday. His group has been a major force in the protests.

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Leader of Cartel Is Captured
item.description: The leader of one of Mexico’s largest cartels, Héctor Beltrán-Leyva of the Beltrán-Leyva gang, has been captured, the authorities said Wednesday night, giving President Enrique Peña Nieto another high-profile victory against organized crime.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Scrutiny in Texas to Detect Whether Ebola Has Spread
item.description: Officials said they believed the patient, a Liberian, had come into contact with 12 to 18 people, including five children.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The family of Marthalene Williams, an Ebola victim, said Thomas E. Duncan helped take her to and from a hospital in Monrovia last month.

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Shipwreck in Arctic Identified
item.description: The wreck of a ship discovered last month after being trapped in Arctic ice in the 1840s has been identified as the H.M.S. Erebus.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Push for a Confidence Vote
item.description: The Greek government said Wednesday that it would seek a vote of confidence in Parliament next week in a bid to quash mounting speculation about early elections and to keep flagging economic reforms on track.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Egypt Seizes Newspapers to Censor an Article
item.description: The censorship is another example of restrictions on news media freedom since the military takeover in July 2013 that put Abdel Fattah el-Sisi into power.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Netanyahu Sees Arab Alliance Aiding Mideast Peace
item.description: The Israeli prime minister said he saw promise in an Arab alliance against the Islamic State, but President Obama focused on Israeli settlements as an impediment to Middle East peace.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel met with President Obama at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Vatican City Journal: A Papal Decision Leaves Some Feeling Less Than Charitable
item.description: A decision by the Vatican to take over the business of issuing Papal Blessings has infuriated vendors who have been selling the benedictions for decades.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Mocnik says she will have to close if she can no longer sell parchments for Papal Blessings.

item.title: In Japan, Fear and Panic as a Revered Peak Explodes
item.description: The eruption of Mount Ontake in central Japan on Saturday, which has so far left 47 people dead, took experienced mountaineers and locals by surprise.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Japanese soldiers and firefighters searched near the peak of Mount Ontake in central Japan on Wednesday. So far, 47 bodies have been found after Saturday’s eruption.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Message for Beijing Hidden in a Hong Kong Street Poem
item.description: On a busy street in Hong Kong, a poem carried a hidden message for the Communist Party as democracy demonstrations shook the city.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: New Afghan Leader, Putting Focus on Graft, Revives Bank Fraud Inquiry
item.description: Trying to fight corruption, President Ashraf Ghani ordered a review of a case that saw only a few of the 21 convicted offenders incarcerated in a so-called $800 million Ponzi scheme.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani, second from right, with administration officials. The decree was meant to reassure Western partners.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Scott Moore on Moving China’s Water from South to North
item.description: Scott Moore, an expert on China’s water policies, discusses why the Chinese government has committed so much money and effort to the South-North Water Diversion Project, which will carry water from the Yangtze River and its tributaries and channel it to northern China, where water shortages are worsening.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Workers in Cangzhou, Hebei Province, reinforcing a pipeline as part of the South-North Water Diversion Project, which aims to relieve China's drought-ridden north by transferring water from the south.

item.title: France Produces a ‘No Austerity’ Budget, Defying E.U. Rules
item.description: The plan defers bringing the budget deficit within a European threshold until 2017, as Paris said that a more rapid shift would harm the economy.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: “We have taken the decision to adapt the pace of deficit reduction to the economic situation of the country,” said France's finance minister, Michel Sapin.

item.title: Despite Truce, Deadly Attacks Persist in Ukraine
item.description: Witnesses said that a biology teacher, a parent and a rebel fighter were killed in one attack in Donetsk, which took place on the first day of school.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Putin Supports Project to ‘Secure’ Russia Internet
item.description: Mr. Putin said a plan to isolate the Internet in Russia was only intended as a backup security system to keep Russian domains online in a national emergency.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: ISIS Takes a Kurdish Village in Syria as Car Bombs Kill Dozens in Homs
item.description: Islamic State militants swept into a Kurdish village near the Turkish border, while in the western Syrian city of Homs, twin car bombings killed at least 45 people.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KARAM SHOUMALI and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Liberian Officials Identify Ebola Victim in Texas as Thomas Eric Duncan
item.description: Senior Liberian officials said the man, Thomas Eric Duncan from Monrovia, had helped a woman who had Ebola to the hospital a few days before he left for the United States.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The body of Sonny Boy Williams, 21, hours after he was picked up alive from his home in Monrovia, Liberia. The man who flew to Dallas and was later found to have the Ebola virus, identified by Liberian officials as Thomas Eric Duncan, helped Mr. Williams carry a woman stricken by Ebola to and from a hospital last month. The woman, Marthalene Williams, 19, died the next day.

item.title: Charges Dropped Against British Terrorism Suspect
item.description: Moazzam Begg, 46, had been held since March after being accused of aiding terrorist groups in Syria; he said he visited the country on humanitarian missions.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: News Analysis: Australian Premier Moves Swiftly Against ISIS, but Analysts Question Benefits
item.description: As Prime Minister Tony Abbott responds to President Obama’s call to combat the Islamic State, analysts wonder what Australia has to gain from such a risky operation.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia sent 600 military personnel to the Middle East to join the American-led mission against the Islamic State.

item.title: Outracing Vows of Aid, Ebola Swamps a City in Sierra Leone
item.description: Ebola is sweeping into areas of West Africa that had been largely spared the onslaught. The consequences in one Sierra Leone hospital have been devastating.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: In Indonesia, Stage Is Set for Battle Over Future of Democracy
item.description: The new Indonesian Parliament opened on Wednesday, under the control of political forces seeking to limit democracy and thwart the president-elect, Joko Widodo.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
